talk.start.para: âby leaveâI move:

speech.para: That the Senate expresses its deep regret at the death, on Saturday, 17 July 1999, of the Honourable Kevin Eugene Newman, Lt Col (Rtd), AO, a member of the House of Representatives for the division of Bass in the State of Tasmania from 1975 to 1984, Minister for Administrative Services from 1980 to 1983, Minister Assisting the Minister for Defence from 1980 to 1982, Minister Assisting the Prime Minister in Federal Affairs and Minister for Productivity from 1979 to 1980, Minister for National Development from 1977 to 1979, Minister for the Environment, Housing and Community Development from 1976 to 1977, and Minister for Repatriation from 1975 to 1976, places on record its appreciation of his long and meritorious public service and tenders its profound sympathy to his family in their bereavement.

Kevin Newman was born on 10 October 1933 in Sydney, New South Wales. He was educated at Scots College and entered the Royal Military College, Duntroon in 1952. He had a distinguished military career. Some of the highlights included service in Malaya from 1956 to 1957 as an infantry platoon commander during the Malayan Emergency and in Vietnam from 1967 to 1968 with the Second Battalion, Royal Australian Regiment. He also served as an exchange instructor with the British Army's School of Infantry.

Kevin Newman won the seat of Bass in Tasmania at a by-election in 1975, a result which was generally credited as contributing in a major way to the change of government that occurred at the general election later that year when he, of course, won the seat again. In fact, he held the seat for some nine years before resigning undefeated in 1984. As I indicated a moment ago, he served as a minister in a number of different portfolios between 1975 and 1983, thus through the whole of the period of the Fraser government.

He had many interests and made a special contribution in so many areas of public life, but I want to mention just two. The first was his long interest in heritage matters, both during his parliamentary service and after. As I said, he was Minister for the Environment, Housing and Community Development when the Australian Heritage Commission was established in 1976. He had been Chairman of the Governing Council of Old Parliament House since 1998, a member of the Stockman's Hall of Fame board since 1985, Chairman of the Australian Council of National Trusts and President of the National Trust of Tasmania from 1988 to 1991.

The other field I wanted to mention was his contribution to the promotion of community health. He was Chairman of the Tasmanian Committee of Nurse Education from 1986 until 1989. He was instrumental in establishing the Menzies Centre for Population Health Research at the University of Tasmania, and its chairman from 1987 to 1990. He was Chairman of the Launceston Public Hospital Board from 1985 until 1989.

Madam President, Kevin Newman was named in the 1994 Queen's Birthday Honours list and appointed an Officer in the General Division of the Order of Australia for service to the community, particularly through the provision of health care services, the preserva tion of cultural heritage and services to the Australian Parliament.

His was a lifelong commitment to community service in his own right, but also of course after his retirement, in support of our colleague Jocelyn. The Newman family continued to serve through the parliament when Jocelyn was elected to the Senate and since she has served as a minister in the Howard government. His support of Jocelyn in her work, particularly as his health deteriorated, is something which we all admired. They made a formidable political partnership, Madam President, both in Tasmania and in the affairs of the nation.
On behalf of government senators, I extend to Jocelyn and their children, Campbell and Kate, and their families our most sincere sympathy in their bereavement.

talk.start.para: âI wish to associate the opposition with this condolence motion moved by the Leader of the Government in the Senate on the death of the Hon. Kevin Newman, who was a former minister in the Fraser government.

speech.para: There is no doubt that Kevin Newman contributed much to Australian society, first serving his country as a soldier, then, of course, as a parliamentarian and federal minister and then in public service. He had a distinguished career in the military, rising to the rank of lieutenant colonel. He graduated from Duntroon in 1954. He was a platoon commander in the Third Battalion, Royal Australian Regiment during the Malayan Emergency in 1956 and then served as an operations officer in the Second Battalion in Vietnam in 1967.

Of course, he resigned his commission to enter the political arena in 1975. He did so at the Bass by-election which he won for the Liberal Party. There is no doubt that it was one of the most significant by-elections in Australian political history. That would be acknowledged by people on all sides of Australian politics. Soon after he won that cathartic by-election in 1975, there was a change of government and he quickly assumed ministerial responsibility. He held numerous portfolios throughout his ministerial career as Minister for Repatriation, Minister for the Environment, Housing and Community Development, Minister for National Development, Minister for Productivity and Minister for Administrative Services.

Those of us in the parliament who have an interest particularly in environmental protection would acknowledge the very significant efforts that were made during his stewardship of the environment portfolio in saving Fraser Island from sand mining. That ought to be placed on record in this chamber today. After that distinguished ministerial career, he resigned from parliament in 1984 due to ill health. As Senator Hill has indicated, it was not long after that that his wife, Jocelyn, entered the Senate and Tasmanians were represented by another Newman in the Commonwealth parliament.

I want to say this: Kevin Newman's death does have particular significance for senators, because his wife is a serving senator and minister in the Howard government. He is a person who was seen around this building a lot, in support of Senator Newman as she undertook her ministerial responsibilities and duties. I am sure that, because of the fact that Kevin Newman was married to a serving senator in this chamber, his death has touched senators very deeply.

The opposition would acknowledge that Kevin Newman served the people of Tasmania and of Australia with distinction. We particularly want to say to Jocelyn Newman that she has the sincere and deepest sympathy of the opposition in this difficult time. We also offer our sincere condolences to other members of Jocelyn's family and to Kevin Newman's friends.

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: âI am indebted to Senators Lees, Brown, Harradine and Boswell for allowing me the opportunity to say a few words on this occasion. Kevin Newman was someone that I had known for more than 20 years. In all that time he always struck meâand, I am sure, many othersâas someone who represented the highest ideals of commitment to public service. His CV is a very impressive one. I suppose the stand-out is that in a political career that spanned only about nine years, for 8Â½ of those years he was a minister. That is a very hard thing to beat and in many ways it tells you a couple of things about judgment: you have got to know when to get in and when to get out. Given that he had already had a very distinguished military career, to move on in the way that he did and hold some very high offices over that long period is ample testimony to his capacity.

speech.para: But CVs do not ever really tell the full story. Certainly, they do not indicate the very human qualities that Kevin Newman possessed. He always struck me as a person of very high principle. We all know that he suffered from a degenerative illness that finally cost him his life. During all of that period when it was increasingly difficult for him to breatheâ and indeed, at times, to moveâhe displayed the highest stoicism and bravery. I am sure that his military career stood him in good stead in that regard. It is very easy, I am sure, for even those who think they are of the strongest character to feel sorry for themselves on occasions, but we never saw that with Kevin. I an sure he was forever grateful for the support of Jocelyn; they were a wonderful team.

I also knew, having appointed him as chairman of the governing council of Old Parliament House and discussing with him such things as the Stockman's Hall of Fame on a number of occasions, of his long and abiding interest in heritage issues. He was a very good chairman. He consulted widely, had the noblest of instincts and very much understood what was important. He was at all times committed to ensuring that we had bipartisan support on that council, that people understood the significance of the building and that we really did leave something for those coming after us.

I simply want to say that most people who go through this parliament can claim that they have achieved something, but Kevin Newman will live long in all our memories as someone who really did bring a new, very high dimension in terms of personal qualities. I am sure that his family and friends will miss him for a very long time. I extend my special sympa thies to Jocelyn, the children and the wider family.

talk.start.para: âI rise to associate the Democrats with the motion moved by Senator Hill. We were all very sorry to hear of the death of the former minister and member for Bass, the Hon. Kevin Eugene Newman AO. He certainly was a very strong and very well-known advocate for Tasmania. The Hon. Kevin Newman's distinguished record, both before he entered politics in 1975 and also while serving in the other place, is also very well known and has again been detailed here this afternoon. In particular, he will be remembered for his work on the environmentâas has already been mentionedâon some of the key issues in his time as a minister in the Fraser government.

speech.para: He went on, yet again, after leaving politics, to a third life, if you like, and did very distinguished work in the community, for which he was formally recognised. We also remember his work for community health and particularly for the National Trust and the environment generally. I want to extend the sympathy of the Democrats to his wife, Senator Jocelyn Newman, and to say to her now that our thoughts are with her at this very difficult time and are also with the family and with Kevin Newman's friends.

talk.start.para: âI wish to associate the National Party with the condolence motion, moved by Senator Hill for the government, for the Hon. Kevin Newman AO, who passed away suddenly in July after a long battle with illness. Kevin was known to many of us in this chamber, and I wish to express our deepest sympathy to his wife, Senator Newman, and to the family.

speech.para: Kevin Newman was a leader before reaching federal parliament. He had a distinguished career in the military, reaching the rank of lieutenant colonel. He graduated from the Royal Military College Duntroon in 1954 and was a platoon commander during the Malayan Emergency in 1956. He then served as an operations officer in South Vietnam. In 1967 he resigned from the military to pursue a future in politics. Kevin's political life began with the now famous by-election in Bass, where he won the seat with a swing of over 17 per cent. This victory was critical for the Liberal Party and began a series of events culminating in the election of the Fraser government.

After the election win, he was appointed as a minister and, over the next eight years, held the portfolios of Repatriation; Environment, Housing and Community Development; National Development; Productivity; and Administrative Services. Kevin Newman will be remembered for his strength of command both during military operations and as a minister of the Crown. In the words of my former leader Tim Fischer, Kevin was a soldier's soldier who enjoyed the company of all ranks. He pushed the envelope to keep moving the battalion forward and to build up unit spirit. He applied the same philosophy of thinking and actions in the portfolios he managed.

Due to ill health, Kevin Newman retired from parliament in 1984. After this, he continued to pursue public service and was appointed president of the National Trust of Tasmania and chairman of the National Council of National Trusts. He was a member of the board of the Menzies Foundation and a director of the Stockman's Hall of Fame. He was also the chairman of the council for Old Parliament House. Kevin Newman received the Order of Australia in 1994 after a lifetime of service.

I extend my sympathy to his wife, Senator Newman, his children, Campbell and Kate, his grandchildren, family members and friends, and offer them the condolences of the National Party. Senator Newman was fortunate to have such a terrific supporter in Kevin.

It is rare to have a husband and wife team where both have played a significant role in public life, each in their own way. We will miss seeing Kevin's face in the corridors. We will miss learning of his involvement in various activities, always related to some kind of public service. It is fashionable for some to downgrade people who try to make their mark in politics, but it is moments like this condolence motion today when we can renew our faith in the importance of a life called to public service. We recognise the sacrifices and triumphs and how important it is to have someone to share them with. Our sincere sympathies are with Jocelyn on the loss of her partner and a memorable Australian.

talk.start.para: âI too would like to associate myself with this condolence motion. It was a great privilege for me to be present at the service for Kevin Newman at the chapel of the Royal Military College, Duntroon. It was a very fitting farewell. Indeed, the eulogies were quite outstanding, I thought, and must have been of considerable comfort to Jocelyn and to her family.

speech.para: Kevin I knew as a fellow Tasmanian as well as a minister for some years. Kevin was, there is no doubt about it, a battler for Bass. He continued talking about Bass, and certainly talked about it within the spheres of government and power up here in Canberra, as witnessed in some of the practical results that flowed to the division of Bass. It has been mentioned that for eight of his nine years he was a minister, but it is interesting to note that he actually stood four timesâhe had to face four elections in those nine years. Such was life in those days. It is not terrifically well known by people nowadays, but he was a senior military officerâa lieutenant colonelâat the age of 41. It is not too often that people get to be lieutenant colonel at the age of 41. He had shown a great deal of spirit, administrative capabilities and, of course, bravery.

There are a lot of things that could be said about Kevin on both a personal and an official basis. I, too, would like to join with my colleagues in expressing sincere sympathy to Jocelyn and to her family on the death of her husband and their father.

talk.start.para: âI, too, would like to associate myself with this condolence motion. In the passing of Kevin Newman, Tasmania and Australia have lost a very fine citizen.

speech.para: I am one of those who seem to have made a career in finding dispute with ministers for the environment, and the former minister Kevin Newman was no exception. But, as has already been mentioned by Senator Alston, a very important part of his success story is the protection of Fraser Islandâone of the great moments in environmental history which occurred under the Fraser government during the time Kevin Newman was Minister for the environment.

I would add that Kevin Newman was somebody with the noblest instincts. He did not bear grudges, and he was an affable, accommodating, genuine human being. I found that in my dealings with him right down the line. I do not know whether it was the inspiration of Launceston's remarkable architectural heritage that made the difference, but he was a fighter for Australia's heritage; a person who has contributed greatly to the wellbeing of the heritage of this country.
I would like to join other members in extending deepest sympathy to Senator Newman and her family at this time.

talk.start.para: âI wish to be associated with this condolence motion. For many years Kevin and I shared adjoining offices.

speech.para: Kevin Newman will be fondly remembered by many residents of Tasmania, particularly the electorate of Bass, as a leader and as a high achiever who represented his people very strongly in the federal parliament. Kevin brought a new and a very practical dimension to federal-state financial relations, especially in the delivery of massive financial special payments to Tasmania.

His landslide success in the Bass by-election in June 1975 lit a spark which quickly led to a revival of Liberal Party prospects nationwide and the subsequent election success of the coalition government later that year. Tasmanians elected Liberals to all five seats in the December 1975 federal election.

As a member of parliament, Kevin Newman was accessible and respected, and regarded as an energetic and warm human being. He also had a distinguished life in community service which began with his military career.

Kevin Newman played an important role during his time in parliament not only as a hardworking and practical minister but also as the major voice for Tasmania in the Fraser government. Of course, we see his loving and so capable wife Jocelyn as the major voice for Tasmania in this very effective Howard government. What a wonderful partnership both Kevin and Jocelyn have been.

Kevin Newman was an energetic and determined advocate of Tasmanian causes, and after his retirement from parliamentary life he continued his strong contribution to community affairs, notably through his leadership role in the National Trust at both state and federal levels. Tasmanians have indeed lost an exceptionally good citizen. Kevin's advice and practical contribution to all will be sadly missed. My sincere sympathy is extended to Jocelyn, his daughter Kate, his son Campbell, his sister, his brother-in-law and also their families.

talk.start.para: âI, too, as a Tasmanian senator, wish to be associated with this condolence motion. Senator Abetz, who unfortunately has had to attend another meeting, would also like his name to be associated with the motion.

speech.para: Those of us who were privileged to be at the memorial service held for Kevin on Thursday, 22 July, could not have been impressed more, not only by the number of people who were there but by the eulogies that were given by former and current serving members of the Defence Force. They spoke about just what sort of person Kevin Newman was. They went right back to when he was serving as a cadet officer and spoke about his military career. There were many enlightening anecdotes about some of his achievements and about some of the pranks that one would expect from young officers and young cadets. Without going through all of his achievements, I think it is important for us to remember that it was mentioned at the service that Jocelyn, his wife, described their relationship as `more than a love affair, but a great friendship'. This was mentioned in Partners, a book about Australian couples who have been together for a long time. I believe the Newmans were together since 1 July 1961.

My major association with Kevin concerned his management of all of the campaigns that I have been involved in. I have been re-elected successfully every time, and I think Kevin's success rate as the director of the Senate campaigns in Tasmania is second to none. Those of us who worked with Kevinâincluding Senator Watson and meâknow that he would tell us in no uncertain terms what he thought we should be doing. His zest to get on and win inspired us all. He suggested that we should hire a bus to do our cam paigning. Without going into any detail, I can assure you that driving a bus with Jocelyn, Shirley Walters and Brian Archer was something that was an experience to be involved in. I was the driver, and half the time I was being advised by everybody which turn we should be taking. Nevertheless, we got around, we won the campaign and we were re-elected. Kevin's support and advice to the Tasmanian Liberal Party, to the federal Liberal members and senators, was always appreciated and very well regarded because his advice was always the best.

A lot of us probably do not realise how well Kevin was known by the man in the street, because of his involvement at all levels. Particularly in Launceston he tenaciously followed through all of his promises. He was involved in very great projects in Tasmania, such as the Australian Maritime College, the Launceston General Hospital and the Albert Hall convention centre. And, of course, he was one of the original supporters of freight equalisation.

Kevin was a very strong family man and supported Jocelyn, as we all know, very strongly, particularly after she became a very senior federal minister for Tasmania. I would like to express my condolences publicly to Jocelyn and her family and, as I said before, involve Senator Abetz in those remarks, because he unfortunately could not be here.

talk.start.para: âI also, as a Tasmanian Liberal senator, wish to be associated with this condolence motion for Kevin Newman. As my colleague Senator Calvert just said, Kevin managed our Senate campaigns going back a long time. Kevin was the manager of the two campaigns that I have been involved inâin 1993 and just last year in 1998. He made a great contribution to the party, to Senator Eric Abetz and me, and to other candidates. He stayed cool, calm and collected throughout the election campaigns and planned them well. Basically, when panic was going on here and thereâwhich happens a fair bit during election campaigns, as we all knowâKevin was there, cool, calm and collected, making sure that things were done correctly; `Settle down. This is what you've got to do,' et cetera. Through that process, of course, my wife and I became good friends with the Newmans.

speech.para: One little thing I should mentionâwhich nobody else has doneâis that Kevin, when national development minister, was a great proponent of a cable across Bass Strait to link the Tasmanian electricity system to the mainland system. This was well before it was even mentioned in the public arena. I might add that that project is underway right now, and not before time. It should have been done a long time ago. Kevin pushed that strongly in the early daysâwhich, again, is not well known in Tasmania. Kevin showed great foresight, and it would have been a magnificent thing if it had been done when he had suggested it. He was a great fellow. We will miss him, and our condolences are with Jocelyn and his family.

talk.start.para: âIn joining in this condolence motion may I say that I well remember 28 June 1975, the date of the Bass by-election, because on that same weekend there was a meeting of the federal Young Liberal policy committee in Melbourne, and I was among seven or eight Young Liberals gathered at that meeting. I think our attention was fixed more on what was happening across Bass Strait in Launceston on that afternoon of the by-election rather than on the matters of policy that were confronting us. There was certainly a terrific celebration among that group on that Saturday evening when the results came in and we discovered there had been an 18 per cent swing to Kevin Newman as the Liberal candidate to secure victory for him in that by-election.

speech.para: Of course, that meant he became the vanguard of the tremendous 1975 election win for the Liberal and National parties, and their return to government under Prime Minister Fraser. He was the vanguard of those who became known as the oncers: those of us who were elected to this parliament for the first time in 1975 were described as thus by the then Labor oppositionâI suppose, in their hoping scornâbut in fact most of us turned out to be at least thricers and survived through the period of service that the Fraser government gave to Australia.

Significantly, Kevin Newman survived beyond 1983 until his voluntary retirement in 1984. It is worth reflecting that, prior to his election, Bass had been a relatively safe Labor seat and certainly since his retirement in 1984 it has been a marginal seat which has seesawed backwards and forwards between the Liberal Party and the Labor Party. Yet Kevin Newman held that seat for the whole of his period in parliament, without loss, and retired voluntarily. I believe that in itself reflects the positive attitude that the electorate of Bass had towards Kevin Newman, the respect they had for him and for the hard work that he undertook on behalf of his Bass constituents.

My closest association with Kevin Newman was during his period as Minister for Environment, Housing and Community Development between July 1976 and December 1977 when, as minister for that portfolio, he initiated the Fraser government's policy to take an active involvement in youth affairs, with the establishment of the Office of Youth Affairs within his department. This was a tremendous initiative on the part of the government, and on the part of Kevin as the responsible minister, because it was the first time that a federal government had taken an active interest in youth matters. It was therefore an important initiative by Kevin Newman, as minister, and something for which he is due great credit.

He appointed me to an advisory committee to work with him in relation to youth affairs policy. During the period he held that portfolio, I was very much aware of Kevin's unbridled enthusiasm not only for life but for his political responsibilities, and that was certainly reflected in his approach to youth affairs and the policies that he initiated in that area and in his work with that advisory committee.

After Kevin's retirement, and my return to the parliament in this place, I continued my association with him on his periodic visits to Canberra, as has already been mentioned, in his capacity as our colleague Senator Jocelyn Newman's spouse. I always regarded highly the opportunity to catch up with Kevin during those visits. Perhaps even more import antly than those visits were his regular attendances at the oncers dinnerâthe reunion dinners that have been held every year for those of us who were elected in 1975âas a `75er, albeit, as an early `75er because, as I said, he was elected in that June by-election rather than the December election.

He was always enthusiastically involved in those dinners and it was of course on those occasions that Senator Newman attended as his spouse, as Kevin attended those dinners in his own right. He certainly enjoyed those occasions and I am sure he will be missed by those of us `75ers who continue to gather each year to celebrate at those dinners. His company will be missed and his enthusiastic involvement in those dinners will certainly be missed. I wish to extend my sympathy to Jocelyn, and to his children and other members of the family.

talk.start.para: âI wish to contribute briefly to this condolence motion for Kevin Newman. Kevin is someone I too will always remember because I was a Young Liberal in 1975 when this fellow called Kevin Newman won the seat of Bass in Tasmania. It was a memorable time for young people, particularly of the Liberal persuasion, because he became the masthead for a Liberal government and a Liberal change. Even though none of us knew Kevin at that stage he was somehow etched in our memories for ever more. Once I got to know Kevinâthroughout my time in the Liberal Party and in those early days when I was involved at national conferences and so forthâI learned very quickly that he was someone who was absolutely and utterly respected as a professional, intelligent and kind person. He was a member of parliament who was able to keep and exhibit all of those qualities, without compromise.

speech.para: One of the wonderful things was that he continued to contribute through his subsequent community activities, which Senator Hill mentioned in his speech earlier today. Apart from being a loving and deeply caring family man, who was so incredibly proud of his wife, Jocelyn, and her achievements, and of course their children, he was also someone who cared about others. When Kevin asked you how you were, or what you had been doing and what you planned to do, he actually meant what he asked. To me, he was one of those rare persons who listened to and were interested in your response. He did not ask the question and then not listen and walk away. It is something I will always remember him for with great affection. To Jocelyn, Kate and Campbell, and their families, I extend to you my heartfelt sympathies at the passing of a person I call a real officer and a gentleman.

talk.start.para: âI also seek to associate myself with the comments that have been made this afternoon about Kevin Eugene Newman. He is fondly remembered by all Tasmanians. His life was an example to us all. It was a life of public service: service to the defence of his nation and service to the people of Bass and Tasmania as an elected member of the parliament and as a minister in the Fraser government. All of us here dedicate ourselves to public service. It would be fair to say that Kevin Newman did that, but even more so. He dedicated the first part of his life to military service, which is a calling potentially a lot greater than the calling of those of us who serve in the public arena. He was willing through his calling to place his own safety at risk for the defence of the nation, and that is a calling and commitment that should never be underestimated.

speech.para: After having completed a very distinguished military career, he continued to devote himself to public service through the parliament. He was prepared to make a commitment to Australia even after his distinguished military and parliamentary career. His support to the Tasmanian division of the Liberal Party of Australia was very much appreciated by me in my role as a former state president and as a Senate candidate at the last election. We were ably managed by Kevin Newman; he was our campaign manager. Throughout the numerous years that I have known Kevin, he struck me as being intelligent, forthright and a very matter-of-fact type of man. He would be very quick to tell you if he thought you had done something wrong. It was over in a minute or two, but it was just as forthright. He would also go out of his way to tell you if he thought you had done something well.

He was very matter-of-fact, straight to the point and strategic, but he was also a man who was very generous in spirit. There is one image that I have of Kevin Newman and that is his big smile and twinkling eyes. Those of us who were at the service at Duntroon saw that those characteristics have been inherited by his son, Campbell, who was so gracious as to smile and who showed the same twinkling eyes as we were passing on our condolences. The Newman duoâKevin and Jocelynâwere a dynamic duo in Tasmania. They have made a fantastic contribution to Tasmania. Indeed, it was Kevin Newman's initiative that basically brought about the Bass Strait freight equalisation scheme in the Fraser government. It was through Jocelyn being the senior representative from Tasmania that, at the last election, we got the upgraded Tasmanian Freight Equalisation Schemeâthe Bass Strait passenger vehicle equalisation scheme.

All those benefits to Tasmania can be shown to have come from the commitment of the Newmans. One thing that also impressed me at all times about Kevin and Jocelyn was their personal closeness and commitment to each other. The rigours of public life do take their toll, but it was quite obvious that Kevin and Jocelyn made time to ensure that their private life was not adversely affected. Can I say, on behalf of the Liberal Party in my home state of Tasmania, that Kevin will be remembered as a hero of the Liberal Party, especially given his efforts in the 1975 Bass by-election. He will be remembered as an activist and a worker. On behalf of all Liberals in Tasmania and especially my wife, Michelle, I offer our sincere condolences to Senator Newman, Kate and Campbell.

talk.start.para: âI wish to associate myself with the condolence motion for Kevin Eugene Newman. My colleagues have spoken about his distinguished military career. I have to mention that, at the funeral service, Senator Calvert referred to the amusing story about Kevin Newman having arrived at Old Parliament House in a pair of army pyjamas, when he was dumped there by some of his military colleagues. I think that showed the sense of fun that he had then, a sense of fun that he never lost.

speech.para: His parliamentary career has been referred to and the fact that he served almost all of his parliamentary career as a minister. People have referred to the achievements of that ministry. Others have referred to his community service in a wide range of areas since he left parliament. I cannot do anything better than quote from the words of Kevin himself from the book, Partners, which Senator Calvert referred to. I want to read an extract from that book:
There aren't too many New Age guys in my generation.
I think that most of us of my age could say, `Hear, hear,' to that. The extract continues:
It's enjoyable supporting Joc and keeping the home running, simply because she now has her chance to follow a challenging career which she never had while she supported me.

As we know, he was often up there in the gallery when she was answering questions in question time. I know that he kept the home running because I benefited from a great number of meals that he cooked. Also, when I stayed there, he always gave me Milo before I went to bed. So I fondly referred to him as my `Milo man' and that name stuck for the whole time that I knew Kevin. It is really about my `Milo man' that I am speaking and I am reading extracts from his book. He went on in the book Partners to say:

Over recent years we have each had to look a doctor in the eye while we were told we were not immortal. In my case I contracted lupus which in turn attacked my lungs. I now live with an incurable lung disease which is getting worse.

I think he showed the practicality of being able to face the fact that he was not immortal with great strength and courage. I think that was something to be admired and most of us would wonder whether we would have that same courage.

Kevin also talked about Jocelyn's illness in this book. He said that those two thingsâthe fact that he was ill and the fact that Jocelyn had been illâwere pretty hard to come to terms with. But he went on to say:

But it can also be enormously positive. The heightened appreciation of life, love, family and friends is something to be experienced. Every day is special and to be lived to the full. It also helps to put the problems in perspective. Political attacks, be they ever so cruel, are not really of enormous importance. Just to be alive and loved counts for more than fame and fortune.
There is a real message for all of us in those few words. He then went on to say:

We think fortune has smiled on us. When we married it was for love. But we all know that choosing a mate for life can be a pig-in-a-poke. For us, a long marriage has worked. We have been blessed with great children and grandchildren, we have both had important and influential careers, but best of all, we are still best mates.
I think that sums up Kevin to a T. In all those difficulties, he still saw the positive side.

I was overwhelmed to be asked by the family to read a lesson at the service. I said to Jocelyn afterwards, `I am sure Kevin would have said, "Good on you, Jocelynâat least you had one girl participating in the funeral service."' He was truly one of the few New-Age guys of his generation. That lesson was from Ecclesiasticus, from the Apocrypha, chapter 44, verses 1 to 15. It started by saying `let us now give praise to godly men'. It was a wonderful reading. It went on:
But we will praise these godly men, whose righteous deeds have never been forgotten. Their reputations will be passed on to their descendants, and this will be their inheritance.

His reputationâas Senator Knowles saidâas an officer and a gentleman will be passed on to his descendants and will be their inheritance. We said let us praise godly men: Kevin was a godly man, a gentleman and a gentle man. My sympathy goes to Jocelyn, Kate and Campbell, and his grandchildren, whom he absolutely adoredâand we often saw him with them in the corridors here and having a coffee, especially at Aussies. My deepest condolences and sympathy go also to his sister, his extended family and his friends.

talk.start.para: âKevin Newman was indeed a very fine man with a very strong commitment to his community and to his family. Tom and I wish to offer our condolences to Jocelyn, Kate, Campbell and their family. I would ask honourable senators to stand in silence to signify their assent to the motion.

interjection.para: Question resolved in the affirmative, honourable senators standing in their places.

talk.start.para: âIt is with deep regret that I inform the Senate of the death on 3 July 1999 of former Senator the Hon. Reginald Bishop AO, a senator for the state of South Australia from 1962 to 1981, and at various times in that period Minister for Repatriation, Minister Assisting the Minister for Defence and Postmaster-General.

talker.name: Hill, Sen Robert
Senator HILL
talker.role: Environment and Heritage

talk.start.para: âby leaveâI move:

speech.para: That the Senate expresses its deep regret at the death, on Saturday, 3 July 1999, of the Honourable Reginald Bishop, AO, a senator for the State of South Australia from 1962 to 1981, Postmaster-General from 1974 to 1975, Minister Assisting the Minister for Defence from 1972 to 1974 and from June to November 1975, and Minister for Repatriation for 1972 to 1974, places on record its appreciation of his long and meritorious public service and tenders its profound sympathy to his family in their bereavement.

Reginald Bishop was born on 4 February 1913 in Adelaide, South Australia. He left school at 15 and commenced work with the South Australian Railways at Islington as a clerk. From the very beginning Reg was an active member of the trade union movement and had a lifelong interest in industrial relations matters more generally. In that vein, before entering federal politics Reg worked as an official with the South Australian branch of the Australian Railways Union from 1937 until 1956. He became a full-time organiser for them at just 24 years of age. Reg was the Secretary of the South Australian Trades and Labour Council from 1956 until 1962 and during this time was also Commissioner of the South Australian Board of Industry. In addition to this, Reg was a member of the South Australian Advisory Committee on Workmen's Compensation from 1957 until 1961 and an Executive Member of the ACTU from 1956 until 1962.

In fact, Reg's lifelong support for workers was a feature of his parliamentary service. In his maiden speech Reg spoke of matters such as the economy and unemployment in his typical no-nonsense manner. During World War II, Reg Bishop enlisted in the Royal Australian Air Force. He served from 23 February 1943 until his discharge on 4 January 1946. During this time he served in Darwin and in Borneo. Reg Bishop entered federal parliament in 1962 having been elected to the Senate for South Australia the previous year. He was re-elected to the Senate a further three times, leaving parliament at the expiration of his term in 1981. Reg Bishop's contribution to the parliament included his considerable committee service. This included serving on many committees, including the Senate Standing Committee for the Library, the Senate Standing Committee for Regulations and Ordinances, the Joint Committee of Foreign Affairs, and the Foreign Affairs and Defence committee, as it subsequently became. He also spent some time on the Senate Select Committee for Container Method of Handling Cargoes during 1967-68 and did numerous periods on Senate estimates committees. Reg also participated in various delegations, conferences and visits during his Senate career.

The aspect of Reg Bishop's distinguished service for which he will perhaps be best remembered will be as the last Postmaster-General of Australia. In this capacity he oversaw the creation of Telecom and Australia Post. Other initiatives included the abolition of television and radio licence fees and the part he played in the introduction of FM radio in Australia. In 1984 Reg Bishop was appointed an Officer in the General Division of the Order of Australia for his service to politics and government. He will be remembered by all who knew him and served with him as a passionate trade unionist as well as a dedicated senator and minister. Sadly, Reg Bishop lost his wife, Connie, in 1997 after, I understand, more than 60 years of marriage. On behalf of the government, I extend to his children Romola and Phillip and their families our most sincere sympathy in their bereavement.

talk.start.para: âI associate the opposition with the condolence motion that has been moved by the Leader of the Government in the Senate on the death of Reg Bishop, a former minister in the Whitlam government. There is a great deal of sadness and regret in the Labor Party at Reg Bishop's death. He was truly a great Labor stalwart. I think it makes many of us realise that, of the figures who were so important and instrumental in the reforms and changes that occurred in this country in the early 1970s, that special time in Labor politics, a number are now disappearing from our lives.

speech.para: Reg Bishop played a vital role in the Whitlam government, but for a very long period of time he had been a very significant figure in the Labor Party in the state of South Australia. He was one of those people who, in the 1950s and 1960s, really built and revitalised the South Australian Labor Party. I am sure he will be remembered by so many in the Labor Party for his loyalty and his dedication to the party and the broader Labor movement. He was one of those no-nonsense people, dedicating himself and his life in tireless work for the Labor cause.

Reg Bishop was a son of South Australia. He worked in the South Australian Railways from an early ageâas a teenager. That really was the first step in his becoming very involved with the union movement which, again, was a lifelong commitment for him. Reg became a full-time organiser of the Australian Railways Union at the age of 24 and, except for a comparatively short period of three years when during World War II he served in the Royal Australian Air Force, he worked for the Australian Railways Union until 1956 when he became the Secretary of the South Australian Trades and Labour Council.

In 1961, as we have heard, he became a senator; he was elected in 1961 and his term commenced in June 1962. That was the commencement of a very distinguished 19 years in the federal parliament. But the highlight was his being appointed minister in the Whitlam government, first as Minister for Repatriation and Minister Assisting the Minister for Defenceâhe was appointed to those portfolios in 1972âand then in 1974 he became Postmaster-General, the last person to hold that position in Australian politics. As Postmaster-General he oversaw enormous changes. One of the biggest changes in the postal and telecommunications arena that we have ever seen made by an Australian government, the creation of those two separate entities now known by the Australian community as Australia Post and Telstra, was in no small measure due to his administrative and political skills and his vision as Postmaster-General.

I would like to say, in speaking on this condolence motion, that Reg Bishop will be remembered by people in the Labor Party as someone who was a true believer. He was a hardworking, straight-talking bloke who served his country with distinction but always had such great pride in the Labor Party and the Labor movement. In relation to the Labor movement, the name of Reg Bishop became a byword for loyalty. He made a great contribution to the Labor movement. He was a great stalwart of the Labor Party, and we will never forget that. On behalf of the opposition, I express sincere sympathy to members of his family and all his friends and supporters in the Labor Party and the broader Labor movement in South Australia. This was truly a great Labor man who died recently and whose contribution we remember today in the Senate.

talk.start.para: âI wish to associate the National Party with the condolence motion moved by the government for Reg Bishop who passed away in July, aged 86. Reg Bishop was born in Adelaide and spent the majority of his life representing the people of that state both in the union movement and in the federal parliament. His working career began in the railways. He then served in the RAAF during World War II with postings to Darwin and Borneo.

speech.para: Reg Bishop had a long involvement in the union movement. He began as an official for the Australian Railways Union and later served as union secretary of the South Australian Trades and Labour Council, Commissioner of the South Australian Board of Industry and executive member of the ACTU. Reg Bishop represented the people of South Australia as a senator for almost 20 yearsâfrom 1962 to 1981. During his distinguished parliamentary career Reg Bishop served Australia as the Minister for Repatriation, the Minister Assisting the Minister for Defence and Postmaster-General. Reg Bishop was the last Postmaster-General and undertook one of the largest administrative reforms in Australia's history by creating Australia Post and Telecom.

As a minister in the Whitlam government, he played a role in some of the most controversial political events in Australian history. After retiring from the Senate in 1981, Reg Bishop led a full and active life and continued to be involved in the South Australian Labor Party. I wish to extend the sympathy of the National Party to his children, family and friends.

talk.start.para: âI rise to associate myself with the condolence motion on the passing of former Senator Reg Bishop. It was a particularly sad occasion for me and my wife personally when we received the news that Reg had passed away, because during the halcyon days of the Whitlam government I had worked on Reg's staff for over two years. I was his senior private secretary both when he was Minister for Repatriation and Minister Assisting the Minister for Defence and when he was Postmaster-Generalâthe last Post master-General in Australia's history. I will return to that shortly.

speech.para: Reg gave me great advice, assistance and comradeship during the time I worked for him. When I first went to work for him I was 24 years of age, a very young and enthusiastic supporter and member of the Labor Party. But Regâbeing an experienced, wise trade union leader and a long-serving senator for the Labor Partyâoffered much useful advice to me and to others, particularly young people, about the way to make one's way through the often Byzantine nature of the Labor Party, the way to treat others and the way to work out the upside and downside of politics.

The two years I spent with Reg on his staff was the most valuable learning experience that I have had in politics. I had previously studied politics for three years at Adelaide University. Reg taught me more in three weeks than I learnt in three years at Adelaide University on the theoretical side of politics. What Reg taught me in practice has stood me in very good stead through all the years I have been involved in the Labor Party, both as an official and as a member of parliament.

Reg's career was a great one for the Labor Party. He grew up in the west end of Adelaide, a traditional Labor area in the 1920s and 1930s, in an overcrowded working-class suburb that is no longer there because of the change in the urban demography of Adelaide. But Reg was very proud of the fact that he was a west end kid. At the age of 15 he left school and got a job as a clerk with the South Australian Railways in the very late 1920s. Because of his active mind, he became very active as a young clerk in the trade union movement in his workplace at the Islington railway workshops.

In 1937, at the age of 24 or 25, he became a full-time organiser for the ARU, the Australian Railways Union. He used to tell me about being provided with an old motorbike to go touring around the rural areas of South Australia, particularly Eyre Peninsula, on gravel and dirt roads, visiting those small townships on the narrow-gauge railway of Eyre Peninsula to organise for the union. He was in that union for nearly 19 years, apart from the three years he served in the Royal Australian Air Force in Darwin and in Borneo during the Second World War.

In 1956 he stood for election as secretary of that union and was defeated in a ballot at the time of the Labor Party split. It wasâin his terms, to me and othersâthe most disappointing part of his life in the labour movement that he was defeated for that position of secretary. But, just as a defeat in the Labor Party sometimes opens up other new opportunities, within six months he had been approached and supported to become Secretary of the Trades and Labour Council of South Australia in 1956. He put his energy into that job and reorganised the Trades and Labour Council of South Australia to make it a more effective organisation that represented the broad trade union movement in South Australia.

At the same time he ensured that the trade union movement in South Australia was working in a united way with the Labor Party to bring about the election of a state Labor government. Reg was one of those people behind the scenes who did an enormous amount of workâwith others such as Clyde Cameron and Jim Toohey and, of course, up-front Don Dunstan and othersâto bring about the election of a state Labor government and ultimately to bring about the election of a federal Labor government. Through all of this period that Reg was active in the trade union movement, the Labor Party in South Australia was getting some of its best election results ever, and Reg should take great credit for assisting in those results.

In the 1961 federal election he was elected to the Senate, taking up his place here in 1962, and he served in the Senate until his term expired in June 1981âsome 19 years. He spent a number of those years on the front bench in opposition and then became a minister, as I have already said, in the Whitlam government. His achievement as Postmaster-General is quite striking. When he took over as Postmaster-General, a royal commission had just been completed which showed that the administration of the Postmaster-General's Department, particularly postal services, was in a dreadful mess. Some may remember the mess of the Redfern mail exchange and the delay in mail deliveries. Reg set about implementing those recommendations to overcome the industrial anarchy that existed, which was brought about not only because of the workers themselves but also because of bad management. He used his considerable knowledge of industrial relations and rapidly improved the situation in the post office.

He also put into place the recommendations to break the PMG up into two new statutory authori tiesâTelecom Australia and Australia Post. This was a massive piece of legislation that went through this parliament in late 1974, early 1975. At that time there were 120,000 employees in the Australian post office and, as far as I am aware, he reorganised the PMG into two statutory organisations without any direct industrial dispute. Reg was a strong believer in public enterprise. He strongly believed in the right for those services of the old PMG to be provided to the community in public ownership. I know he was as distressed as anybody when in 1996 this present government started the privatisation process of what we now call Telstra. That achievement alone will be remembered as a major achievement in anyone's history of the Australian parliament.

Reg retired in 1981 but, being the active person he was, he continued his involvement, support and interest in the Labor Party, the Trades and Labour Council of South Australia and, in particular, the Labour Day celebrations. Reg was always on everybody's back about making sure they turned up at Labour Day marches. He did everything possible to keep the Labour Day march and the Labour Day celebrations going as he saw it as a commemoration of all those people in the trade union movement, going back over 100 years, who had worked to improve the working conditions of ordinary Australians.

As Senator Faulkner said, Reg was a very direct person. He would always tell you very directly and honestly what he thought about an idea, but he never carried a chip on his shoulder and he never carried a vendetta. Within the Labor Party he used to say, `Remember that your political enemy in the Labor Party this month may be your political ally next year. So never close off all your options for dialogue or consultation.' When he became a minister he found that some of the things he was saying as minister in accordance with a government brief were contrary to what he used to say in opposition. He said, `Hansard is replete with contradictions where you change sides from being opposition to government.' He said, `It is always difficult to be 100 per cent consistent but one should always try to be that in politics.'

I believe that Reg Bishop not only at the federal parliamentary level but, in particular, at the state level in South Australia has been one of the half a dozen key figures who has over the last 50-odd years made a contribution beyond any other to the Labor Party's success in South Australia. He was not one to be up in neon lightsâReg did not seek much publicity for himselfâbut those of us who have followed him have lived on the success he created for the Labor Party. It was a very great honour for me to have had the opportunity to work on Reg's staff during those times of the Whitlam government and to have accepted his advice when I became secretary of the party. Through difficult times he was always ready to offer advice when you sought it from him but he never did it in a way that was like trying to tell you how to suck eggs or that he knew better. He was very clever at providing advice in a way in which you could take it and mould your ideas accordingly. Therefore, his passing at the age of 86 is a great loss for the Labor Party in South Australia.

He lived most of this century for the Labor Party in South Australia and his contribution was significant. He worked full time for the Labor Party for over 60 years of his lifeâfrom a mid-teenager to when he diedâand that is a remarkable record. He lost his wife Connie only a couple of years ago. She was a great stalwart and worker for the Labor movement in her own right. He leaves a family and grandchildren who were the delight of his life when I worked for him, and he leaves many great memories for many of us in South Australia. All I can say is: as long as many of us continue in this place and elsewhere in South Australia, his contribution will never be forgotten.

talk.start.para: âI thank Senator Quirke for allowing me to intervene here as I have a meeting at 5 p.m. I do not know whether I am the only one here who was serving in the parliament when Reg was here, but I do remember taking over Reg's office when he became a minister. That was very interesting. His press secretary at the time had left some very interesting material in the drawers. Not being terribly interested in the material, I was able to give it back to Reg.

speech.para: Reg did a lot of unsung work, if you like. It has been observed that he was very direct in what he said. I found him not only to be direct but also to have some very well chosen words. When you discussed some things with him he would use a particular phrase which I will not use hereâit is not obscene, but it is not parliamentaryâand you would know where you stood. He would be able to go through other things with you and discuss them face to face.

The portfolios that he held were indeed portfolios in which he made his mark. He said that he obviously dealt with all people, irrespective of their background, in the same way: he did not waste his words. I think that is an important and likeable characteristic for a member of parliament. I suppose people would say, `It is a pity there are not a few more of you.' I express my condolences to Reg's family, his daughter and son particularly, and to his many friends in South Australia. I associate myself very firmly with this motion of condolence.

talk.start.para: âI wish to be associated with this condolence motion as well. I understand that in Reg Bishop's time here Senator Harradine, Senator Watson and, for a very short time, Senator Reid served with Reg. Reg used to always tell me that the best thing was to live long enough so no-one could actually remember you. Indeed, Reg had a long life. It is very sad for myself and for others who used to meet regularly with Reg. I can quite honestly say that we used to lean on Reg for advice. We used to get very good first-class advice, but we also got a mateship, a friendship, out of it. Indeed, I think it can be said that Reg Bishop was a man who gave himself to the Labor Party, who gave himself to the Labor movement and who gave himself to people. He was always there.

speech.para: Reg had a long life. He was born some 12 years after Federation. His life covered every major political and historical event of this century until a matter of a few weeks ago. Other speakers in here have given biographical details of when he joined the trade union movement, when he first went to workâwhich I understand was in 1927âwhen he became the secretary of the Trades and Labour Council and when he came to the Senate. I want to discuss the importance of this man to the Labor Party and to the Labor movement as such.

I well remember how I met Reg Bishop. I had made some comments at a state council meeting and Reg came up to me. He did not like what I had to say. I cannot remember exactly what it was now. I tried to remember for the eulogy at the funeral. It was something I said which upset one of my great friends, Georgie Whetherall. Neither George nor I could remember what it was, but such was the role that Reg played that I remember him coming up to me in the Trades Hall bar, buying me a drink and then taking me around the corner and saying, `Look, you got this wrong tonight. This is what you should have said,' or words to that effect.

Reg had a way of bringing people together. In fact, when he left the Senate, Reg's role was not only to keep the trade union movement strong in South Australia, to keep the Labor Party strong, but also to foster the next generation of Labor people in federal and state politics. All the political generations were at his funeralâfrom Gough Whitlam and many of the surviving ministers of that period right the way through to many people in Young Labor today and teenagers. They all knew Reg. They looked forward to meeting him. He was the sort of fellow who, when he came into your office, no matter what you were doing or what your staff were doing, they took time to talk with because they knew they were talking to a living legend. It is very sad that Reg is no longer with us. I will miss the many Friday lunches I used to have with him where we would range over topics and I would watch as party members would be in awe of this man and the stories he could tell and the range of views he could bring to any discussion which took place.

I think on the Thursday night before his funeralâin fact, I know that was the night; we had our state councilâan argument erupted at the state council which I found rather interesting at the time. Somebody got upâI will not mention any namesâand invoked Reg's name. They said, `Look, effectively this would never have happened. Reg would never have sanctioned this. Reg would never have done that. Reg would never have done this.' Somebody else got up and took objection to it and said that we should not say that about somebody who so recently had died. In fact, I always took the view, and I still do, that it is better to be remembered that way than not to be remembered at all.

While sitting back listening to this argument going on, I thought it was rather amusing that we were actually sitting in the Bishop Auditorium. And, yes, it was named after Reg Bishop for the work he did to build the Trades Hall in South Australia. Reg was a distinguished politician. He was a distinguished Labor senator. He was a distinguished trade unionist. There are many things which, in the end, could proudly be said are on Reg Bishop's masthead.

He loved his family. He loved his wife. I spoke in here in an adjournment debate in September 1997 when Connie died. Connie had had a stroke. She was not very well at all. She had a very sad and terrible end. For the 18 months or so before that time, Reg was there every day. I quite often used to drive him out to where Connie was. Even at the age of 86 Reg got around. Reg had no problems whatsoever with any kind of mobility. His end came very quickly. In many respects, after what he went through with Connie, I think that that in itself was a blessing.

Reg was a religious man. Reg was a man who believed very strongly in loyalty. Reg was a man who dominated his era in politics here, in South Australia and wherever he was. He was a larger than life figure. I am proud to have known him. Some of my great memories in the Labor Party are the times I spent with Reg, with Jim Toohey and with some of the others who were there. I am grateful that I lived through these times and that I met some of the great men of the Australian Labor Party.

talk.start.para: âI also rise to speak to this condolence motion. I regret that I was not able to be present at Reg Bishop's funeral because I was in the middle of the Tanami Desert at the time and could not get back. But I do take this opportunity to speak not just as a Labor Party senator but also as a former staffer of Reg Bishop. I worked with him initially in the veterans' affairs portfolio, Repatriation as it then was, and also when he was Postmaster-General.

speech.para: I came here in 1981 when Reg Bishop retired from this placeâin essence, I took his place. Reg, as everyone has said this afternoon, was a special person. He was amiable. He had a cheerful disposition. If you got something wrong, he very clearly and quickly told you so, but it did not damage the ongoing relationships within the office. But he was also crafty, cunning and extremely capable, and I think the Senate records would bear witness to that. Many of his achievements have been mentioned this afternoon by Senator Schacht and Senator Quirkeâthose as a trade unionist, a senator and a ministerâbut one thing that needs to be noted about Reg is his humble beginnings. Despite those beginnings, he never let success take carriage of him.

In a sense, Reg and I are and were so different with so many years between us and different cultural backgrounds altogether, but we did ironically share quite a bit, and it was not just the Australian Labor Party and some involvement with the trade union movement. Reg was also a long-time dedicated member of the West Adelaide Football Club, a club of which I was a committee member for some 10 years, and we would always talk about the politics of the club and how the club was going on the field.

But the origin that we did share was where we were both born. Ironically, though, and decades apart, Reg and I were born in Hocking Place in Adelaide, just off Sturt Street and just around the corner from St Vincent de Paul and the Salvation Army and from Whitemore Square. It is a little street with some 14 or 15 houses. I went back there last week for some reason and noticed that very little had changedâmost of them are all 60, 70 or 80 years old. In a sense it is a dead-end street, but it is a street from which two senators of the national parliament have been produced, and Reg and I always talked about the fact that two of us came from a street of about 15 housesâa street that was and continues to be basically in one of the poorer parts of Adelaide. Whitemore Square still has its unfair share of homeless and unemployed frequenting the street, the Salvation Army is still full and St Vincent de Paul still gets a big roll up at about 6 o'clock at night.

We did share that and we did share the essence of being westenders, something that never left him till his death and something that I am sure I will carry with me while I am alive. It was a twist of fate, therefore, that I took his place in the Senate, and I can assure other senators that I was not back in Hocking Place to try to find future Senate candidates for the Labor Party. There are enough of those around already.

I worked with Reg for quite some years. It was my first job in politics. I worked with Chris Schacht, and Reg had as one of his great friends John Quirke. That ambit of friendships, that ambit of personalities, reflected in the three names that I mentioned shows what a special character Reg Bishop actually was. Having had Bolkus, Schacht and Quirke in common as friends makes him an extraordinary character in one sense or another.

We had a bit of history together when in 1974 we were working for the Whitlam government. Between Reg Bishop, Don Cameron, Chris Schacht and me, we started the Chinatown Friday lunch club, which I think continues to exist. The bottles of Ben Ean and moselle that we started drinking in the 1970s have probably run out, and so probably has the Queen Adelaide riesling. Senator Faulkner looks around in surprise, but the Chinatown lunch club still continues as one of those informal institutions of Labor politics in South Australia.

Much has been said of his humble origins. Chris Schacht mentioned the work he did as an organiser with the Railways Union. One thing I am reminded of consistentlyâI was by Reg and I have been by some of his former colleagues in recent weeksâis the fact that, when Reg was an organiser out in the peninsula, out in the back blocks, his one form of mobility was a pedal bike as opposed to the cars that are available now. He was not afraid of hard work and dedication. He was also crafty. Senator Harradine mentioned one of the words that Reg would often use, and it is a word that appears in the story I am about to tell.

I remember being with him in the AMP building when he was Postmaster-General and it was the lead-up to budget decision making in 1974 and the Postmaster-General's Department advised him that the price of local calls had to go up and there was no option but to increase them by a large amount. The reasons were technical: all the telephone boxes across the country could not take anything other than 20c as opposed to the then current rate of 5c or thereabouts. Reg's response was, in a sense, one word. It starts with frog, the next two letters are `sh', and he basically told the senior officers that there was another way around it. They insisted that they were right, but he told them all to jump into the car with him. They drove down to the local PMG depot and spoke to a local mechanic who assured him that what he wanted to do could be done, which consequently put senior officers of the Postmaster-General's Department back in their box.

Reg, as Chris Schacht said, was a giant in Labor politics and, as Senator Quirke mentioned, was so till the end. Connie was an important part of his life, and we all got to know and cherish relationships with her. In summary, I will say that Reg Bishop was one of West End's best. I also offer my condolences to his family.

talk.start.para: âI wish to join in supporting this condolence motion for former Senator Reg Bishop. Most everything that needs to be said has been said. I just wanted to put on the record my own particular and special experience of Reg Bishop. He retired from the Senate just as I arrived into it, but he belonged to a special group of Labor Party people in South Australia who were extremely strong in encouraging women into the Labor Partyâand I would include amongst those people like Mick Young, perhaps first and foremost, Jim Toohey and Geoff Virgo, to name some of them. People like Reg Bishop, I know and acknowledge, contributed to my being given the nod for preselection for politics in South Australia.

speech.para: That may not be a characteristic that distinguishes him or makes him mighty by many people's criteria, but it certainly does by mine. But it was also not a fashionable view at the time. It is important to remember that for a while there the Labor Party was way out in front with the preselection of women and that we could be successful in House of Representatives or Senate preselections only if men in the Labor Party supported us because the women in the Labor Party could not achieve that; they did not have 50 per cent. Regretfully, I suspect it is probably true that they still do not have 50 per cent, and one would not presume that all women would necessarily want to vote on the same side.

talk.start.para: âThey judge other women pretty harshly.

âI would think this would be a point that you would have great sympathy for, Senator Hill. Unanimity of view or support, I guess we are talking about here, whatever the gender. So I think that is the first thing I would have to note about Reg.

speech.para: Secondlyâand this word has been mentioned alreadyâReg was unfailingly generous and unfailingly prepared to listen. No matter what time of day or how tired he was, Reg was always prepared to give an ear and pay serious attention to what you were saying. He did not have that `I've got to go, come back later' attitude. `Generous' is the word I would use about Reg.

Reg and Connie were a duo of the same characterâexactly the same. It is a pity we cannot in some way find the words that would so fully describe these people who were, until the time of Connie's death, really devoted to each other and to their families, their children and grandchildren. They were also very supportive of each other. If Reg wanted to promote and support an aspiring young Senator Rosemary Crowley, then Connie would too. Not that she followed Reg; she made up her own mind. Likewise, if Connie were to support an issue in the Labor Party, then Reg would join her in that.

Quite clearly, they were people of independent mind and different opinion but also very able to talk things through and arrive at a point of agreement. In fact, I think Connie belonged with a special group of women called the Hawker Ladies in the federal seat of Hawker who at one stage were very able to explain to the men in the Labor Party that, despite what the men in the Labor Party thought about the role of women in the Labor Party, these women were about to tell them their description was not sufficient; and they proceeded to set in motion and establish the so-called Hawker Ladies, who worked for the Labor Party, raised funds for the Labor Party, supported all sorts of candidates over many years and were characteristic of the party at the timeâto do with generosity, to do with an understanding of what the Labor movement was on about, to do with why it was so important to have Labor governments and to make sure that the people they worked for were represented by legislation, programs and services which would ensure that they were able to live the kinds of lives they wanted, to make things okay for them but in particular to make it better for their kids. Reg and Connie were quintessential, core Labor Party people of that mould and they belong, I think, to a very special piece of history in the Labor Party in South Australia. I appreciated the support over many years of the Hawker Ladies.

Connie Bishop and Reg Bishop were a team. They were unfailing in their generosity and their contribution, for those values that they held so very dear they in fact lived out through their day-to-day living. There was no `now I am at the Labor Party' and `now I am going to be an ordinary citizen'. The values that they held dear were the sorts of values they believed in the Labor Party, in their family, amongst their friends and in all the community and charitable work that they were involved in. They were actually splendid exemplars, and it is a shame that we will now depend on stories told about them rather than the full oral histories that perhaps we have missed the opportunity to really get from such people.

I want to put on the record my appreciation of them for being the sort of people they were in that they were able to model that without ever looking for their name in lights; never did they seek that. But they were a model couple of the sorts of values that were so dear to their hearts. I also want to acknowledge that they were great supporters of mine. I would like to place on the record that until the day I die I will appreciate their supportâtoday, in particular, Reg Bishop's support.

That does not cover the important things that others have said about Reg's origins in West Adelaide and his contribution to the union movement and politics. I can only concur with everything my colleagues have said. I wanted to take this opportunity to put my somewhat different appreciation of Reg and Connie on the public record and also to take the opportunity to convey my deepest sympathy to their children and grandchildren on the loss of two very special people.

talk.start.para: âby leaveâI move:

speech.para: That the Senate expresses its deep regret at the death, on Thursday, 8 July 1999, of the Reverend Doctor the Honourable Malcolm Mackay, AM, a member of the House of Representatives for the division of Evans in the State of New South Wales from 1963 to 1972 and Minister for the Navy from March 1971 to December 1972, places on record its appreciation of his long and meritorious public service and tenders its profound sympathy to his family in their bereavement.

Malcolm George Mackay was born on 29 December 1919 at Brighton, South Australia. Malcolm was educated at the Adelaide Technical High School and, after finishing school, became a cadet engineer with the Adelaide Electric Supply Company.

Malcolm was a man of several careersâpublic, private and parliamentaryâall earnestly pursued and complementary to his central faith and values. During World War II, Malcolm was mobilised as a sublieutenant in the Royal Australian Naval Volunteer Reserve from 1941 until 1944, during which time he served in the New Guinea area. He was discharged on demobilisation with the rank of acting lieutenant.

After the war, Malcolm Mackay studied at the universities of both Adelaide and Melbourne, gaining a Bachelor of Arts and a Bachelor of Divinity, before working his way to Britain where he enrolled at the University of Edinburgh and gained his doctorate degree. Malcolm then returned to Australia and began a long and distinguished career with the Presbyterian Church. From 1954 until 1956 he was the General Secretary, Australia, for the World Council of Churches; in 1957 he became the first Australian-born minister of Sydney's Scots Church; he was the Foundation Master of Basser College at the University of New South Wales from 1959.

Malcolm Mackay entered federal parliament as the member for Evans in 1963. He served the McMahon government as Minister for the Navy from 1971 until he left the parliament in 1972. During his parliamentary career, Malcolm served as Chairman of the House of Representatives Select Committee on Pharmaceutical Benefits from September 1970 until March 1971. He was a member of the parliamentary delegation to Indo-China in 1970 and led an Australian parliamentary mission to Japan and Korea in 1972. One of his many achievements was becoming founding president of the Association of Former Members of the Parliament of Australia. He remained an executive member of the association until his death.

Malcolm's public activities included conducting a weekly current affairs television program, The Burning Question, from 1957 until 1961 before moving to the ABC for the program Open Hearing from 1963 to 1971. Malcolm Mackay's concerns for the young people of Australia were clear throughout all of his public activities and, indeed, from the start of his parliamentary career. In his first speech he spoke extensively on the need for educational resources. He praised youth as `having a zest for living and an inquiring mind'.

After he left the political scene in 1972, he spent five years in Scotland, much of the time writing articles and a book, More than Coincidence. In 1979 he was Assistant Minister of Scots Church Melbourne and Acting Minister at St Andrew's Presbyterian Church, Canberra in 1991. His enthusiasm for, and faith in, the future of Australia was recognised when in 1986 Malcolm was appointed as a member in the Order of Australia for service to the community, particularly in the fields of religion, education and politics.

Tragically, Malcolm Mackay was killed in a motor vehicle accident which also claimed the life of his wife of over 40 years, Ruth. On behalf of the government, I extend to their children Andrew and Margaret and to their families our most sincere sympathy in their bereavement.

Dr Malcolm Mackay. talk.start.para: âI rise to associate the National Party in the Senate with the condolence motion, moved by Senator Hill on behalf of the government, for the Hon. Dr Malcolm George Mackay, who passed away with his wife last month at the age of 79. Malcolm Mackay was born and raised in Adelaide.
