talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Aged Care, upon notice, on 16 March 1999:

question.para: (1) Have a number of providers of high-level residential aged care been replacing qualified enrolled nurses with `aged care workers' who have no formal training.

(2) What was the ratio of qualified nursing staff, both registered and enrolled nurses, to residents in high-level aged care facilities, by state, in the 1996-97, 1997-98 financial years and to date in the 1998-99 financial year.
(3) Under the Aged Care Act what mandatory requirements are placed on providers to employ qualified nursing staff.
(4) Can a provider operate a high-level aged care facility without any qualified nursing staff present.
(5) Are the daily care subsidies paid by the Commonwealth to providers based on the award rates for qualified nurses.
(6) Have the dependency levels of residents in high-level aged care facilities increased.
(7) Can the Minister confirm that Principle 3.8 `Nursing Services' is not being applied to low-level care facilities that retain residents who require high level care.

talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator Herron
talker.role: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Aged Care has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1), (2) and (3) The Commonwealth Aged Care Act 1997/Part 4.1/Division 54-1(b) states that providers of aged care must `maintain an adequate number of appropriately skilled staff to ensure that the care needs of care recipients are met.' Service providers must be able to demonstrate this to the Aged Care Standards and Accreditation Agency. The Quality of Care Principles of the Aged Care Act 1997 are measured by outcomes and therefore, the Act does not prescribe ratios of nursing staff to residents.

The Aged Care Act 1997, Quality of Care Principles, Schedule 1/3.8, lists complex nursing procedures which, for high care residents, must be carried out by a registered nurse or other professional appropriate to the service (eg. medical practitioner, stoma therapist etc). The Principles also state that, for these services, `Initial and on-going assessment, planning and management of care for residents, [must be] carried out by a registered nurse'.

(4) All high care residents must by virtue of Schedule 1/3.8 in the Aged Care Act 1997, Quality of Care Principles have `Initial and on-going assessment, planning and management of care for residents, carried out by a registered nurse'. In addition, this Schedule lists complex nursing procedures and states they must be carried out by a registered nurse or other professional appropriate to the service (eg. medical practitioner, stoma therapist etc).

(5) The care subsidies are based on resident care needs as assessed through the Resident Classification Scale (RCS). The Commonwealth pays a higher level of subsidy in relation to residents with higher care needs.

Under the RCS, all residents are assessed against Question 18âTechnical and Complex Nursing Procedures, which itemises complex nursing services under List 2. Such procedures `will be carried out by a registered nurse or other health professional appropriate to the particular procedure, based on initial and ongoing assessment, planning and management of the care recipient's care by a registered nurse. Examples include medical practitioners, stoma therapists etc.'
If a resident requires these complex nursing services and, hence the input of a trained nurse, their RCS rating will increase and consequently so will the subsidy paid to the facility under the RCS.

(6) The introduction of a new Resident Classification Scale in October 1997 makes it difficult to compare dependency levels of current aged care facility clients with clients assessed under the previous instruments.

It is, however, possible to compare the dependency levels of people already in residential aged care facilities with the dependency levels of people entering care since October 1997. When such an assessment is done, the dependency level is shown to have increased by 1.54%.
(7) Principle 3.8 Nursing Services applies to all high care residents who need the listed procedures regardless of the type of aged care facility in which they are living.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Family and Community Services, upon notice, on 21 May 1999:

question.para: (1) Is a working parent who lives in a permanent relationship with a partner who has a child from a previous relationship and a child to the present relationship entitled to claim both children and his partner as dependants for the purposes of the Child Support (Assessment) Act; if so, what benefits is the parent entitled to through Centrelink.
(2) Are there any limits placed on Centrelink allowances payable to the second family; if so, what are the limits.

talker.name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
Senator Newman
talker.role: Family and Community Services; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) Formula assessments of child support are based on the income of both natural and/or adoptive parents, and take into account a parent's duty to maintain any other natural children. Therefore, a parent who is paying child support for a child of a previous relationship, and who has a natural child in a new relationship, can claim that child as a dependant for the purposes of the Child Support (Assessment) Act 1989.

If a person forms a relationship with a partner who already has a child in their care, the partner remains entitled to receive child support from the child's parent. The child support will still be based on both of the parents' incomes. The new partner's income will not be taken into account.

The circumstances of parents and children may change in many ways, as new relationships are formed, but the underlying principle of the Child Support Scheme is that the natural and/or adoptive parents remain financially responsible for supporting their children. Accordingly, the fact that a parent has formed a new relationship does not, in itself, have any bearing upon his or her child support assessment.

The working parent could be entitled to Parenting Payment, Family Allowance Childcare Assistance and Family Tax Payment from Centrelink, subject to meeting the income and assets test and all other requirements. However, only one of a couple can receive Parenting Payment, so normally the non working partner would claim parenting payment and be eligible for a higher rate. Similarly Family Allowance and Family Tax Payment are usually paid to the primary carer. When calculating the family income for Family Allowance and Childcare Assistance, 50% of any child support paid by the partner would be deducted from the family income.
(2) Otherwise, Centrelink entitlements payable to a second family are identical to those payable to other families.

From 1 January 1999 child support payers with second families are able to claim 50% of any child support paid as a deduction from the household income used for determining the family's entitlement of Family Tax Payment and Childcare Assistance.

subdebateinfo.title: Goods and Services Tax: Funding for the Alice Springs to Darwin Railway
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 1149)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Re gional Services, upon notice, on 25 June 1999:

question.para: (1) Will the goods and services tax (GST) be payable on the Federal Government's $100 million funding to the Northern Territory Government for the Alice Springs to Darwin railway.
(2) Will the GST increase the cost of construction of the proposed Alice Springs to Darwin railway; if so, how much will a GST add to the overall cost of construction.

talker.name: Macdonald, Sen Ian
Senator Ian Macdonald
talker.role: Regional Services, Territories and Local Government

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Transport and Regional Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) The Commonwealth's commitment of $100 million from its Centenary of Federation Fund for the construction of the Alice Springs to Darwin rail link will constitute a taxable grant for the purposes of GST. $30 million of the grant is expected to be paid in this financial year under the existing taxation regime and the remaining $70 million to be paid in subsequent financial years and will be subject to GST.
(2) The Treasury advises that the GST should not add to the cost of construction of the railway, and is more likely to result in a reduction.

This is because, while a business will have to pay GST on its inputs, it will receive input tax credits for that tax. This makes business inputs effectively not subject to the GST, which together with the abolition of the existing wholesale sales tax and certain other State taxes, produces a cost saving.

In turn the business will be liable to GST on the value of goods or services it sells and would pass this on in its price. The price increase from the tax reform should be an amount equivalent to the GST, net of cost savings from the abolition of existing indirect taxes.

This effect will apply to the construction of the railway as much as to any other business activity. During the construction phase, the railway will be able to claim input tax credits for the GST on goods and services used and, if the credits exceed tax liabilities, obtain a refund of the tax paid.
